skill.name: scientific-brainstorming
skill.description: Creative research ideation and exploration. Use for open-ended brainstorming sessions, exploring interdisciplinary connections, challenging assumptions, or identifying research gaps. Best for early-stage research planning when you do not have specific observations yet. For formulating testable hypotheses from data use hypothesis-generation.
skill.summary: Guides creative scientific research ideation through structured brainstorming techniques and collaborative exploration.
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill with no executable code. Static findings triggered on benign markdown text about brainstorming methodologies. No network calls, no external commands, no filesystem access. Safe for publication.

content.value_statement: Scientists often struggle to generate novel research directions during early-stage planning. This skill guides creative scientific ideation through structured brainstorming methodologies, helping researchers explore interdisciplinary connections and identify hidden research opportunities.
actual_capabilities: Guides researchers through five-phase brainstorming workflow from context understanding to next steps
Applies structured methodologies like SCAMPER, Six Thinking Hats, TRIZ, and Biomimicry
Facilitates interdisciplinary connections by drawing parallels across scientific domains
Challenges assumptions and encourages unconventional research perspectives
Synthesizes ideas into concrete research directions and action items
limitations: Does not access external databases or live literature search capabilities
Cannot verify scientific validity of generated hypotheses through experimentation
Effectiveness depends on user providing sufficient research context
Not designed for hypothesis testing or data analysis tasks

use_cases.title: Explore New Research Directions
use_cases.description: Graduate students use the skill when stuck on thesis direction or seeking novel angles on established research questions.

use_cases.title: Cross-Disciplinary Innovation
use_cases.description: Established researchers apply techniques to bridge their domain with adjacent fields, discovering unexpected methodological connections.

use_cases.title: Team Ideation Sessions
use_cases.description: Research teams use structured techniques during planning meetings to ensure diverse perspectives and avoid groupthink.

prompt_templates.title: Initial Research Exploration
prompt_templates.prompt: I am working on [research area/topic]. I want to brainstorm some novel research directions. Let me describe my current work: [describe your research context, goals, and challenges]. Ask me questions to understand my domain, then help me explore creative new directions.

prompt_templates.title: Apply SCAMPER Framework
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to improve my current research approach using the SCAMPER framework. My method involves [describe your current methodology]. Walk me through each SCAMPER element and help me generate modified versions of my approach.

prompt_templates.title: Six Perspective Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: I am evaluating whether to pursue [specific research idea]. Help me analyze this from all six perspectives of the Six Thinking Hats method. Guide me through White, Red, Black, Yellow, Green, and Blue hat thinking.

prompt_templates.title: Cross-Domain Innovation
prompt_templates.prompt: I work in [your field] and want to discover connections to [target field]. My current challenge is [describe the challenge]. What concepts, methods, or approaches from [target field] might offer new perspectives?

output_examples.input: I'm studying how cells respond to stress and want to brainstorm novel research directions.
output_examples.output: Some intriguing angles to explore: What if you examined stress responses across different scale boundaries (single cell to tissue-level)? Could you reverse the causal direction and ask what cellular stress does to surrounding non-stressed cells? Consider borrowing concepts from ecological network theory to model cell communities rather than isolated responses.

output_examples.input: I want to design self-healing materials using biological inspiration.
output_examples.output: Nature offers several strategies worth examining: How do salamander limbs achieve regeneration without scarring? What molecular mechanisms allow vascular systems to self-repair? Consider the cascade structure of blood clotting as a model for distributed healing. Biomimicry could also draw from plant wound responses, which operate without an immune system like ours.

output_examples.input: I need to analyze large datasets but want to find unconventional approaches.
output_examples.output: Try flipping the analysis hierarchy: Instead of starting with hypotheses, let the data reveal its own structure through emergent pattern analysis. Consider applying concepts from topological data analysis used in neuroscience. Could you invert the relationship and use the data to generate questions rather than answer them?

best_practices: Maintain a conversational balance where the researcher does at least 50 percent of the talking and idea generation.
Push beyond obvious ideas by explicitly encouraging risky and unconventional research directions.
Adapt techniques to the researcher's thinking style rather than rigidly following predefined frameworks.
anti_patterns: Do not lecture the researcher or dominate the conversation with AI-generated ideas.
Avoid forcing specific brainstorming methods when the natural conversation flow is productive.
Do not let AI-generated ideas substitute for the researcher's domain expertise and judgment.

faq.question: What types of research questions work best with this skill?
faq.answer: This skill excels at early-stage research planning where the goal is generating novel directions. It works well for exploring interdisciplinary connections, improving existing methodologies, and identifying research gaps.

faq.question: Can this skill help with interdisciplinary projects?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill explicitly draws parallels across scientific domains and uses techniques like Biomimicry and cross-domain analogies to connect ideas from different fields.

faq.question: How long should a brainstorming session last?
faq.answer: A productive session typically runs 30 to 60 minutes. The skill guides researchers through five phases: context understanding, divergent exploration, connection making, critical evaluation, and synthesis of next steps.

faq.question: Does this skill work with all Claude models?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill is compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. The conversational brainstorming approach works across all models with varying levels of creative exploration.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with my existing research workflow?
faq.answer: Use the skill during planning phases before experiments begin. The output of each session should be concrete next steps such as literature searches, pilot experiments, or collaboration opportunities.

faq.question: When should I not use this skill?
faq.answer: Avoid this skill when you already have specific hypotheses to test or when you need data analysis. For hypothesis formulation from existing data, consider using the hypothesis-generation skill instead.
